Typo – Please note that this word is better written as two words, without the "hyphen" ; therefore this may be considered as a Global correction as well. Attention Jim Funderburk, Merriam-Webster agrees! Please note that, Andhrabharati has suggested that such corrections as this should not be made. But the simple fact is this: The online Cologne Dictionaries are presenting a "New Edited Edition" of each dictionary by making "print changes", according to authoritative approval. The only question remaining is this: "For what reason, should we limit such corrections?". Print changes are being made, this is a fact! But why should there be some "print changes", and not others? I prefer a thorough and consistent approach to editorial corrections. The evolution of language is unstoppable! So why try to "stop", the inevitable?

Typo – Please note that this is a suggested "print change". The word "annumeration" appears to be considered "obsolete". I know that Andhrabharati likes to retain obsolete words, however I prefer to go with the "spirit" rather than the "letter" of the law (so to speak). I hope that Jim Funderburk will give this some thought. Cologne online dictionaries are presenting the "Ultimate Corrected Editions" with "Print Changes" for the benefit of Humanity – and why correct the "Sanskrit" and not the "English" as well? So it is important to be clear when and where to "Draw the Line", and why "Stagnate" the inevitable evolution of language. "Accurate Meaning" should be the "Rule", not "Curating" Archaic and Obsolete words, in honor of the Deceased.

ALSO, there is an important question regarding the "gender" of the compound "kṛtopasaṃbhāṣam". Without the full context, it appears that the gender may be better taken as "Neuter", in an impersonal sense. Please consider the citation above with the following translation:  "conversation or friendly persuasion was (done or made) with a look."  Why Masculine Gender?  Does Andhrabharati have anything to say?

column6: Please note the following statement: "See ūrṇa-mrada and ūrṇā-mradas."  Therefore, I am suggesting that the Missing Headword: "ūrṇamrada" be added (and paired with) the existing Headword: "ūrṇamradas [ID=38090]".  There is no reason to "omit" the Headword "ūrṇamrada", which MW has directly mentioned here. I consider this to be a Worthy Print Change, namely: Adding The Missing Headword!

The supplemental insertion of this Headword should be placed just after the word "ūrṇāvāhi m. [ID=38099.1 sup]" in the Hierarchical listing of words. This reasoning is in keeping with the MW Headword "ūrṇāvat" which is located strictly according to alphabetical order, even though it is formed with the suffix "vat". Therefore, by the very same reasoning the Supplemental Word "ūrṇāyu", formed with the suffix "yus", should likewise be located strictly according to alphabetical order.

column7: Typo – Please note that this is a "Print Change". You may confirm by checking with SHS, LRV, Wilson and Yates. Also check the uttarapada for this compound which must be "apākaraṇa", in order to yield the correct meaning. Furthermore, you will see that this Headword is part of a Three Word Grouping by MW. Thus, while the grouping is to be maintained, the Alphabetical Order must be corrected to reflect this "Print Change". To be specific: the Corrected Headword "ṛṇāpākaraṇa" must now follow the Headword "ṛṇāpanodana [ID=38903]". And lastly, the three related ID numbers must all be corrected to reflect the new order.

Thus, while the grouping is to be maintained, the Alphabetical Order must be corrected to reflect this "Print Change". To be specific: the Corrected Headword "ṛṇāpākaraṇa" must now follow the Headword "ṛṇāpanodana [ID=38903]". And lastly, the three related ID numbers must all be corrected to reflect the new order.

column6: In regard to this "Revision", I am reminded of our discussion last year of treating ALL Revisions in such a way that the Window Display will RETAIN the original definition with a "red line-through markup."  I also recall that Dhaval specifically commented that he "likes this idea", because it allows the user to make an informed decision regarding translation of Sanskrit words, which we all agree are capable of bearing a wide variety of meanings, both literal and metaphorical.  LB I mention this now as a reminder, and perhaps Dhaval would like to add this "New Revision Treatment" to his To Do List – for ALL revisions contained in MW dictionary.

column7: Typo – Better without the "Hyphen". Of course, it should be a Global Correction !

Typo – Please note that this is a suggested "print change". It is a technical point, but please consider that the affix used is defined by Apte himself as: "शस् A Taddhita affix forming adverbs from nouns". Therefore, the affix being "śas" would be better kept as such!  Also, please consider that Apte likes to list masculine nouns as ending in "aḥ".  So the correction that I am suggesting above honors both the actual form of the affix "śas", while providing a visual distinction from the common masculine form. Finally, if there are any other words in Apte dictionary that end in the Taddhita affix "śas", then I am recommending a Global Correction to all such cases following this very example: all indeclinable words listed by Apte as ending in "śaḥ" should be corrected to ending in "śas" – The Actual Affix!

column6: Please note that there are TWO Headwords as: "1. dharā [ID=99757]"  AND  "2. dharā [ID=99842]". The numbering here is my own. But the point is that some Numbering perhaps should be added to the Hierarchy List, to distinguish between the First "dharā" being strictly defined in its own right; and the  Second  "dharā" which heads the related compounds beginning with "dharā-"  acting as the pūrvapada.

Please note that there are TWO Headwords as: "1. dharādhārā [ID=99768]"  AND  "2. dharādhārā [ID=99850]". The numbering here is my own. But the point is that some Numbering perhaps should be added to the Hierarchy List, to distinguish between the First "dharādhārā" being formed with the pūrvapada "dhara"; and the  Second  "dharādhārā" with the pūrvapada "dharā".

column6: Please note that on the printed page, the following four Chief Priests are shown with an initial Capital Letter (and italics): Hotṛ  Adhvaryu  Brahman  Udgātṛ ; LB Thus, these four words should be corrected accordingly in the following enumeration: "viz. hotṛ, Maitrāvaruṇa, Acchāvāka, Grāva-stut; adhvaryu, Prati-prasthātṛ, Neṣṭṛ, Un-netṛ; brahman, Brāhmaṇācchaṃsin, Agnīdhra, Potṛ; udgātṛ, Prastotṛ, Pratihartṛ, Subrahmaṇya". LB Indeed, it is strange to "demote" the Chief Priests being mentioned !

column6: PLEASE READ: As a side note, MW lists the directly related Headword "danīdhvaṃsa [ID=90014]", THEREFORE why not list this Headword accordingly as "sanīsraṃsa" ; Consistency Wins The Day !  Both forms are cited and given under the very same rule: "Pāṇ. ii, 4, 74, Kāś."  I see that the Mahābhāṣya approves of this word "sanīsrasa", however the more common form appears to be spelled: "sanīsraṃsa", just like "danīdhvaṃsa [ID=90014]". MW did NOT print "danīdhvasa", although the Mahābhāṣya approves of this spelling.

column6: The supplemental insertion of this Headword should be placed just after the Headword "ekāntaduḥṣamā f. [ID=39822]" in the Hierarchical listing of words. I am aware that Andhrabharati often disagrees with my suggestions for "relocation" of words. However, in this case I prove my point on the strength of MW's own listing of the following two Headwords: "1. duḥṣama n. [ID=93320]"  AND  "1. duḥkha mfn. [ID=93403]". Each of these two Headwords serve as the "uttarapada" for the two compounds: "ekāntaduḥṣamā"  AND  "ekāntaduḥkha". Therefore given the very same "pūrvapada", namely "ekānta", the alphabetical ordering of these two compounds MUST FOLLOW the same alphabetical ordering as given by MW himself in listing the following two Headwords (which form the uttarapada of the above compounds): "1. duḥṣama n. [ID=93320]"  AND  "1. duḥkha mfn. [ID=93403]".  The ID numbers here Prove the Point: "ekāntaduḥkha" MUST FOLLOW AFTER "ekāntaduḥṣamā".
